relationships.notes: Commands the execution detail at Golgotha, observes the manner of Jesus’s death, and voices the climactic confession about his identity.
Serves under Pilate’s authority, receives Jesus for crucifixion after the governor’s sentence, and later confirms the death when Pilate inquires.

traits.witness_to_jesus_death: As the centurion standing facing Jesus, observes how he breathes his last.
traits.confession_of_identity: Exclaims, 'Truly this man was the Son of God,' offering a striking Gentile confession at the moment of Jesus’s death.
traits.narrative_function: Serves as a climactic human witness in Mark’s passion narrative, recognizing Jesus’s identity at the cross where others mock or abandon him.

traits.shared_witness_with_soldiers: Appears with those keeping watch over Jesus, collectively reacting to the earthquake and other phenomena accompanying his death.
traits.expanded_confession: Proclaims, 'Truly this was the Son of God,' integrating cosmic signs with recognition of Jesus’s status.
traits.role_in_matthean_theology: Functions as part of Matthew’s emphasis on the extraordinary events surrounding the crucifixion and the recognition of Jesus by Gentiles.

traits.response_of_praise: Seeing what has taken place, glorifies God rather than simply expressing awe.
traits.confession_of_innocence: Declares, 'Certainly this man was innocent' (or 'righteous'), underscoring Luke’s concern with Jesus’s innocence.
traits.narrative_role: Provides a Gentile voice acknowledging the injustice of Jesus’s death and contributes to Luke’s portrait of varied responses to the crucifixion.
